abstract.p: Correction of July 18 article on growing prominence of Sikhs in British Columbia

block.p: An article on Tuesday about the growing prominence of Sikhs in British Columbia and Canada's acceptance of diversity referred incorrectly to Adrienne Clarkson, an immigrant from Hong Kong who is the governor general. She is not Canada's head of state; Queen Elizabeth II is.

The article also referred incorrectly to a trade mission to India by Ujjal Dosanjh, an Indian-born Sikh who is British Columbia's premier. While such a mission has been discussed, there are no plans for one in September.
The article also misspelled the surname of a reporter for The Vancouver Sun who commented on the growing links between Indians in Vancouver and in the state of Punjab. She is Kim Bolan, not Boland.

An article on Tuesday about the growing prominence of Sikhs in British Columbia and Canada's acceptance of diversity referred incorrectly to Adrienne Clarkson, an immigrant from Hong Kong who is the governor general. She is not Canada's head of state; Queen Elizabeth II is.

The article also referred incorrectly to a trade mission to India by Ujjal Dosanjh, an Indian-born Sikh who is British Columbia's premier. While such a mission has been discussed, there are no plans for one in September.
The article also misspelled the surname of a reporter for The Vancouver Sun who commented on the growing links between Indians in Vancouver and in the state of Punjab. She is Kim Bolan, not Boland.
